newsitem.title: KUWAIT: U.S. strike against Iraq boosts Kuwait shares.
newsitem.headline: U.S. strike against Iraq boosts Kuwait shares.

text.p: Kuwait share index ended the week to Wednesday at a record high after U.S. attacks on Iraq and the expansion of a no-fly zone in the south of Kuwait's former occupier boosted confidence in security, dealers said.
The index rose 13.3 points or 0.8 percent reaching a record level of 1,636.7 points, bourse officials said.
"Many people believe that as long as the no-fly zone in Iraq has been expanded the Gulf would be safer," said Mohammad al-Duhaishi, a dealer.

Analysts said the expansion on Wednesday of a no-fly zone almost to Baghdad's suburbs will sharply curb Iraqi air power and hand Washington's Gulf allies valuable extra warning time of any potential trouble from Iraq.
U.S. air and naval forces have fired 44 cruise missiles against military targets in southern Iraq since early Tuesday.
Another reason for the increased trade and higher prices is that a September 6 deadline for bad debt payments by private debtors did not cause share dumping, dealers said.
"Worries about the debts deadline ended. Sales were expected to occur on the last day of the week and there was no sign of that," Duhaishi said.

Debtors involved in a plan to settle bad debts owed to the state have to pay an installment by September 6. The debt, with an original value of $20 billion, is owed by businessmen and private companies including listed firms.
Daily average volume rose 93.1 percent to 138.5 million shares, with a total volume of 692.7 million shares.
Traded value gained 74.3 percent on a daily average basis to 25.1 million dinars ($83.9 million), with a total value of 125.9 million. Deals rose 53.7 percent to an average of 1,461 a day.

"The market will be more active next week," said Khaled al-Saleh, chairman of the Gulf Brokerage Company. "Capital is flowing into the market and the results of (listed) companies are expected to be very good."
Gains led losses 27-13, with 15 stocks unchanged.
The most active stocks were Commercial Bank, Investment Projects, United Realty, Pearl of Kuwait Real Estate and Kuwait Real Estate.
Banks were the most active sector by value with 39.4 percent, followed by property shares with 30.7 percent and investment companies with 15.8 percent.
Properties were the most active by volume with 44.6 percent. Banks came second with 26.8 percent and investment firms were third with 17.8 percent.
